Graphical abstract In this experimental study, various NiMo-promoted (as follows: H-beta, H-mordenite, H-USY, H-Y, and H-ZSM-5) catalysts were prepared, tested, and compared with pristine zeolites for the purpose of the gas phase hydrocracking, hydrogenation, and isomerization in a packed bed reactor at 370 °C under atmospheric relative pressure. 5 wt.% naphthalene/95 wt.% 1-methylnaphthalene were selected as biomass tar model molecule compounds, based on real chemical compositions. A series of material characterization techniques were applied to determine the physical structural, morphological, textural, redox, and acidic properties of synthesized catalysts. An outstanding catalytic activity and stability were found over the 2.5 wt.% Ni–2.5 wt.% Mo/ZSM-5 with high carbon deposition resistance, 2-methylnaphthalene selectivity (96.0 mol.%) in the liquid with the products with a yielded total conversion of 96.3 mol.% after an 18 h time on stream, where ethylene/propane were main (94.2 wt.%). The latter can be attributed to the presence of mesopore volume/surface area, existing boundary interface, the amount of medium/strong acid sites, and the synergetic interaction phenomena between metal atom species/supports. Attention should be paid to particle size dimensions, diameters and acidity, which facilitated poly-aromatic hydrocarbon removal. Considering particular obtained distributions, intermediates reaction pathway was proposed. Cracking, synthetic ring opening, alkylation, condensation and disproportionation were additionally involved. Results were consistent with the occurrence of two competing mechanisms, a monomolecular, as well as a bimolecular one. Keywords Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) Biomass-derived ethylene monomer ZSM-5-supported nickel–molybdenum Cracking ring opening Catalytic reaction mechanisms 1 Introduction Biomass is a promising major energy resource, which is renewable and abundant compared to sharp reduced fossil fuels such as coal, petroleum, and natural gas which are causing a growing environmental problems such as the greenhouse effect [1]. Tar is the main obstacle on the way of lignocellulosic biomass gasification. Tar is regarded as one of the most serious problem in biomass gasification due to polymerization of the latter to a more complex structure and can cause blocking, plugging, and cracking pipes, filters and heat exchangers and thus reducing the gasification efficiency and increasing the production costs of biofuels [2]. Moreover, tar contains the complex polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) carcinogenic compounds which is harmful to human and environment [3]. The biomass tar can have a complex and diverse composition with more than 10 000 various compounds (aromatic compounds, PAHs, sulfur-containing hydrocarbons, and oxygen-containing hydrocarbons), while some model compounds such as naphthalene (NP), 1-methylnaphthalene (1-MN), 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN), toluene, benzene, xylene, phenanthrene, anthracene, pyrene, levoglucosan, furfural, hydroxyacetaldehyde, phenol, and cresol can be utilized as the common tar model compounds [2,4]. Naphthalene together with other two ring aromatic hydrocarbons is usually the main part of the biomass tar. Our literature review analysis shows that the most research in this area deals with the light cycle oil (LCO) and less with the real biomass tar or its model compounds (naphthalene, toluene, phenol, 1-methylnaphthalene) which can be converted into benzene, toluene, xylenes (BTX) fraction or tetralin under high pressure (3−10 MPa) or syngas products at high reaction temperature (600−900 °C). For instance, Laredo et al. [5] studied the production of BTX from LCO over mixture (50/50 in weight) of NiMo/Al2O3 and NiMo/ZSM-5(50) catalysts with the optimal reaction conditions for BTX fraction (31 %) being as follows: P =7.4 MPa, T =375 °C, LHSV =1.2 h−1 and a H2/oil = 442 m3/m3. Corma and co-workers [6] investigated the catalytic hydrocracking of the LCO fraction by utilizing decalin and tetralin as model compounds over ZSM-5, MCM-22, ITQ-2, USY, Beta, UTD-1, and MCM-41 zeolite catalysts at 723 K. It was demonstrated that pore size and topology of the applied catalysts have a strong impact on the catalytic performance and selectivity in the ring-opening reaction, transalkylation, dealkylation, hydride transfer and coke formation. In turn, the catalytic cracking of tar from biomass gasification was studied by Chen and coauthors [7,8]. The reaction was carried out over Ni-MgO/HZSM-5 and Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor with an N2 carrier gas (60 mL/min) at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure. It was shown that Ni-MgO/HZSM-5 catalyst is more active and resistant to carbon deposition than Ni/HZSM-5, due to a decrease in catalyst acidity after loading of MgO with 2 wt.%. The main products obtained during the reactions (isomerization, alkylation, decarboxylation, dehydration, hydrogen transfer, aromatization, and decarbonylation) were gaseous products such as H2, CO, CO2, CH4, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8. Lee’s group [9–11] successfully utilized the PAHs such as tetralin, naphthalene and alkyl-naphthalenes for BTX production over Ni, NiSn, NiMo-S, NiW-S, CoMo-S on H-Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 = 75) and H-ZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 30) zeolite supports in a fixed-bed reactor in the temperature range of 425−450 °C under 3−4 MPa. The authors found that NiMo-S on H-Beta zeolite with adding of H-ZSM-5 (10 wt.%) achieved 54.3 wt.% of BTX yield from tetralin (X = 97.6 %) at 425 °C with 4 MPa total pressure. The results obtained over the studied catalyst were explained by the balance between the structural properties and metallic and acidic functions after the appropriate amount of H-ZSM-5 loading, which leads to enhanced alkylbenzenes dealkylation to BTX. In addition, Smith’s group [12,13] showed that Mo2C/HY, KMo2C/HY and MgMo2C/HY catalysts are active for the conversion of naphthalene, tetralin or decalin to ring-opened products at 300 °C under 3 MPa. Finally, Usman et al. [14] studied the hydrogenation of naphthalene (X = 85 %) to tetralin (S = 99 %) in a fixed-bed reactor over MoP supported on H-ZSM-5, H-Beta and H-Y zeolite, where the MoP/HY catalyst was found as the most active at 300 °C and H2 pressure of 4 MPa. In the case of investigations related to the conversion of naphthalene (NP) and 1-methylnaphthalene (1-MN) model mixture, no information was found even when the reaction is carried out under high pressure. Only a few research groups studied 1-MN compound as a feedstock under high pressure. For example, the hydrocracking of the 1-MN was carried out by Park et al. [15,16] over NiMoS supported on alumina-USY catalyst at 360−400 °C under 5 MPa of H2 pressure. The authors established the highest yield of alkyl(benzenes) of about 80–97 %, where tetralin, decalin and cyclo-paraffin compounds were the main by-products. The catalyst deactivation was observed due to coke formation on the USY, which occurred on the acid sites. Ishihara et al. [17] investigated the hydrocracking, isomerization and hydrogenation of 10 wt.% of 1-MN and 0.1 wt.% of dibenzothiophene mixture with decalin as a solvent over NiMo-modified zeolite (H-Beta, H-Y, H-USY, H-ZSM-5) catalysts with various SiO2/Al2O3 ratios and Al2O3 loading in the temperature range of 300−360 °C under 5 MPa reaction pressure. The authors observed the highest yield of BTX over NiMo/Beta catalyst (SiO2/Al2O3 = 37) with the addition of Al2O3 (35 wt.%). It was elucidated that mesopores facilitate the hydrocracking reaction and the acid sites together with the high metal dispersion enhance the high catalytic activity. It is known that the selected naphthalenes composition is the main part of biomass tar [2,4]. The content of naphthalene and other two ring aromatic hydrocarbons can be in the range of 30−85 wt.%, where its composition significantly depends on the type of biomass and reaction conditions. In this work, the solvent was not used because the latter can distort catalytic evaluation study results and do not represent the real biomass tar composition. At the same time, our feedstock composition (5 wt.% NP +95 wt.% 1-MN) can be successfully used for mimicking the behavior of real biomass tar on an industrial scale. This feedstock composition is a significant part of the composition of almost any biomass tar. In addition, our feedstock mixture can be utilized as a liquid feedstock, NP is soluble in 1-MN at room temperature, which is an additional advantage of its application as a biomass tar model mixture. After a detailed literature review, we have also found that only a few groups [18–22] studied the isomerization and disproportionation of 1-MN into 2-MN under ambient pressure. The production of the 2-MN (value-added product) has a great practical interest [23]. It is shown (Scheme 1 ) that 2-MN can be utilized for the synthesis of vitamin K and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (Friedel-Crafts acylation), where the latter can be converted to polyethylene naphthalene (PEN). Guerzoni et al. [18] studied catalytic cracking of binary mixture of 1-MN with n-hexadecane over HY and catalyst mixture of HY and HZSM-5 zeolites at 400 °C under atmospheric pressure. The authors showed that HY zeolite is responsible for isomerization and disproportionation reactions while the addition of HZSM-5 into the latter is responsible for the inhibition of bimolecular hydrogen transfer processes. The highest achieved selectivity of 2-MN over HY zeolite was 83 %. Sun et al. [21,22,24,25] extensively studied the preparation of 2-MN from 1-MN via catalytic isomerization at 300−350 °C under atmospheric pressure. The authors carried out the reaction over pristine and treated HBEA zeolite catalyst, which was dealuminated by oxalic acid and/or hydrochloric acid or desilicated by sodium hydroxide. It was demonstrated that the highest selectivity is in the range of 92.7–96.7 %. Matsuda et al. [19] also studied isomerization of 1-MN over H-Y, H-Mordenite and H-ZSM-5 catalysts at 300 °C under ambient pressure. It was shown that external acid sites are responsible for 1-MN isomerization because diffusion of the latter into the channels is limited by the pore dimensions of the zeolites. Moreover, the high degree of isomerization of the 1-MN is related to the position of thermodynamic equilibrium and the thermodynamic stability of the 2-MN. This statement was also supported by Popova and co-workers [20,23], who found that 2-MN is the thermodynamically stable main reaction product in the isomerization of 1-MN over H-Y, SAPO-5, H-Mordenite, and H-ZSM-5 catalysts at 350 °C under atmospheric pressure. In this work, Ni and Mo metal species as promoters and H-ZSM-5, H-β, H-Y, H-USY, H-Mordenite zeolites as supports were selected based on the literature data as the most active and/or promising catalysts for the conversion of biomass tar model compounds into value-added chemicals. In this study, we report for the first time the hydrocracking and isomerization of a binary mixture of NP and 1-MN over NiMo-bimetallic zeolite catalysts, which are typically present in the biomass tar as the main polyaromatic compounds. This paper describes and compares the structure of the catalysts, acidity, and activity of the pristine and bimetallic-promoted zeolites in the hydrocracking and isomerization reactions under atmospheric pressure in a packed-bed continuous flow reactor. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All utilized zeolites such as HZSM-5(30) – Zeolyst International; Hβ(28) – Tosoh Corporation; HY(5.1) – Tosoh Corporation; HUSY(10) – Tosoh Corporation; H-Mordenite(15) – Tosoh Corporation (numbers in a parenthesis point out on the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of utilized zeolites) were calcined prior to use for removing impurities at 550 °C in the air for 6 h. The preparation of the metal promoted zeolite catalysts involved the impregnation of commercial zeolites using the wet-impregnation method with 372 mL of 0.001 M solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (Merck, 99.98 %) and 426 mL of 0.01 M solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck, 98.5+%). Where the (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O solution was introduced first to the corresponding zeolites with vigorous stirring at 80 °C. The stirring was continued for 3 h. Thereafter, all samples were dried overnight at 110 °C, ground and after that calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in the air atmosphere. Finally, all catalyst powder after calcination was ground an additional time. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption‐ desorption experiments were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument at −196 °C after sample degassing (200 °C overnight with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min). The hierarchy factor (HF) was calculated as follows: HF = (Smeso/SBET)×(Vmicro/Vtotal) [26,27]. The solid phase catalysts crystal structure was identified by powder X-ray diffraction analysis on PANalytical XpertPro instrument using CuKα1 radiation (1.54056 Ǻ) in the range of scattering angle from 4 to 70° with increments of 0.034°. The elemental composition of the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (Optima 8000, Perkin Elmer) after dissolving 20 mg of the sample in a mixture of 2 mL HF (48 %, Sigma-Aldrich), 2 mL of HNO3 (69 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and 2 mL of HCl (35 %, ROTIPURAN® Supra) by chemical extraction under autogenous pressure at 900 W and a rate of 10 W min−1 for 99 min in a microwave oven (Multiwave 3000; Anton Paar). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses were carried out on the electronic microscope FE–SEM SUPRA 35–F (Carl Zeiss) equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer Inca 400 (Oxford Instruments) and the particle size of the studied samples were calculated from the HRSEM images utilizing the ImageJ software. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) - energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) analysis was carried out on JEOL ARM 200 CF microscope equipped with Jeol Centurio EDXS system. The amount of coke was quantified via total carbon (TC) analysis using Rosemount Analytical Dohrmann DC-190. Pyridine Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform (Pyr-DRIFT) spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 equipped with an MCT detector, operating with a diffuse reflectance accessory (DiffusIR) and environmental chamber from PIKE Technologies. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) data was obtained using a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 II instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) coupled to a Pfeiffer Vacuum Thermostar quadrupole mass spectrometer for detection of various species ions with m/z = 15, 18, 28, 30, 32 and 44 for NH3, H2O, N2, NO, O2 and N2O, respectively. The analysis was carried out in the quartz U-tube reactor loaded with 0.1 g of catalyst sample inside. The reactor with sample was heated up to 500 °C in He gas and kept constantly for 1 h to remove all moisture. Thereafter, sample was cooled down to 100 °C in He atmosphere. The·NH3 adsorption was carried out at 100 °C for 30 min by flowing (20 mL/min) of 10 vol.% NH3/He gas mixture. Afterwards, the residue was purged with He at 100 °C for 1 h. Finally, the NH3-TPD measurements were conducted by heating sample in the temperature range of 100−600 °C in He flow (20 mL/min). The rate of heating was 10 °C/min. H2 temperature‐programmed reduction (H2‐TPR) data was collected using the same apparatus model (Micromeritics Autochem 2920 II) with the same amount of catalyst sample (0.1 g). Before each test, sample was loaded in a U-shaped quartz tubular reactor and pretreated in a mixture of Ar/air = 3:1 (20 mL/min) at 500 °C for 1 h and subsequently cooled down to 50 °C in Ar flow. Then, the pretreated sample was reduced in the reduction gas mixture (10 vol.% H2 and 90 vol.% Ar) with a flow rate of 50 mL/min, while the temperature was ramped from 50 to 600 °C at heating rate of 10 °C. The H2 consumption was recorded by a TCD detector. A cooling trap (mixture of ice and isopropanol) was used to remove any trace amount of water. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The experimental setup used for the hydrocracking and isomerization of biomass tar model compounds (5 wt.% of naphthalene dissolved in 95 wt.% of 1-methylnaphthalene) is presented in Scheme 2 . The reaction was conducted in the Microactivity-Reference (PID Eng&Tech) packed-bed reactor [28–30] over 0.5 g (sieve fraction 250−400 μm) of the catalyst at 370 °C. The naphthalene and 1-methylnaphthalene mixture was injected into the hot box at 140 °C by a 307 HPLC Piston Pump (Gilson Inc.). Thereafter, the feedstock was redirected to the catalytic reactor in which the catalyst was first pretreated in N2 at 50 mL/min for 2 h and after that kept in H2 flow at 150 mL/min for 2 h at 370 °C before the reaction was started. The obtained product mixture was cooled down at 0 °C in the Peltier cell and thereafter liquid product was redirected to the second condenser at room temperature which was analyzed offline by GC (Thermo Scientific FOCUS) with FID detector and Zebron ZB-5 Phenomenex (60 m ×0.25 mm ×0.25 μm) capillary column and by GC (Shimadzu, GC/MS-QP2010) with MS and ZB-5MS capillary column (60 m ×0.25 mm ×0.25 μm). At the same time, the gas products were sent to the online micro-GC (Fusion Inficon) with Rt-Molsieve 5A, Rt-Q-BOND, and Rt-U-BOND capillary columns. All main products were quantified via an external calibration method in a wide range of concentrations and verified by a GC–MS. It was found that the main liquid product is 2-MN, while the some low amounts of byproduct traces were found. These were: 1,3-dimethyl-naphthalene; 2,6-dimethyl-naphthalene; 2,3-dimethylnaphthalene; 1,5-dimethylnaphthalene; 1,7-dimethyl-naphthalene; 1,4,6-trimethylnaphthalene; 1,8-dimethylnaphthalene; 2,3,6-trimethylnaphthalene; 1,6,7-trimethylnaphthalene; benzene; toluene; xylenes; anthracene; 9-methylanthracene; indane; 1-methylindan; 1,3-methylindan; 4-methylindan; 2-methyltetralin; 1-methyltetralin; 6-methyltetralin; tetralin; 2,4-dimethylstyrene; 1,2,3,4-tetramethylbenznene; 1,2,4,5-tetramethylbenzene; 1,2,3-trimethylbenzene. In the gas phase product mixture the main identified compounds were ethylene and propane. All gas products were calibrated in a wide range of concentrations. The total conversion of NP and 1-MN conversion, XTOTAL, was calculated using the next equation: (1) X T O T A L m o l % = ( n ( N P ) i n + n ( 1 − M N ) i n ) − ( n ( N P ) o u t + n ( 1 − M N ) o u t ) ( n ( N P ) i n + n ( 1 − M N ) i n ) × 100 % The selectivity of 2-MN, S2-MN, and its yield, Y2-MN, calculated using the equations below: (2) S 2 − M N m o l % = n ( 2 − M N ) ( n ( N P ) i n + n ( 1 − M N ) i n ) − ( n ( N P ) o u t + n ( 1 − M N ) o u t ) × 100 % (3) Y 2 − M N m o l % = n ( 2 − M N ) n ( N P ) i n + n ( 1 − M N ) i n × 100 % where n(NP)in, n(NP)out and n(1-MN)in, n(1-MN)out are the input and output moles of naphthalene and 1-methylnaphthalene before and after the reaction, respectively; n(2-MN) is moles of 2-methylnaphthalene. The experimental error was established based on at least three different experiments and it was in the range from 1 to 3 % for all identified liquid and/or gas products. The total carbon balance was always near to 100 %, which includes the sum of carbon moles in liquid, gas, and coke. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural characteristics The surface area studies by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution and the structural characteristics of zeolite supports and Ni-promoted zeolite catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . BET surface areas of all studied catalysts observed between 300 m2/g (2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5) and 667 m2/g (H-USY). As can be seen in Table 1, the BET surface area and micropore volume of all studied catalysts significantly decreased after Ni and Mo species loading. At the same time, it was found that the mesopore volume increased for the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 (0.15 cm3/g), 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y (0.07 cm3/g) and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite (0.04 cm3/g). It can be seen that the highest mesopore volume is attributed to the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst, which can be one of the main reasons for the enhanced catalytic activity. Besides, Table 1 shows that after Ni and Mo loading the pore diameter for all zeolite supports was increased. The most significant pore diameter increase (from 63.5 to 81.3 Å) was observed for the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. This observation can be explained by the incorporation of Ni and Mo species into the pore structure of zeolite support, which leads to structural defects of the latter and increases the mesoporous volume [31]. According to the literature [31–33], the incorporation of metals such as Ni-Mo, Ga, Zn into pristine zeolite leads to the increased mesopore surface area and mesopore volume due to the formation of an additional amount of mesopores. For instance, Zhou et al. [31] synthesized various NiMo/Y catalysts with different mesopore sizes for the hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene. The authors show that the mesopore surface area of the NiMo/HMY-0 catalyst is approximately 50 m2/g higher than the MY-0 sample due to the formation of mesopores during the ion exchange process. In addition, the authors established that the Vmeso also increased from 0.08 to 0.14 cm3/g after the addition of both Ni and Mo, which is inconsistent with our experimental results. Moreover, Zhou et al. [32] show the effect of Ga addition on the mesoporous HY pristine zeolite and NiMo/Y catalyst. Clearly, the surface areas of the synthesized samples decreased with an increase in the Ga/Al ratio but the mesopore surface areas of the samples followed the order MY-0Ga < MY-0.25Ga < MY-2Ga ≈ MY- 0.5Ga < MY-1Ga. Both the total pore volumes and the mesopore volumes of the samples increase in the order MY-0Ga < MY-2Ga ≈ MY-0.25Ga < MY-1Ga < MY-0.5Ga. Therefore, it is not surprising that the mesopore surface area and volume were increased also in our case after the Ni and Mo species were loaded onto the zeolite support. H-β, H-Y, and H-Mordenite support together with NiMo-doped zeolite catalysts exhibit a typical type I isotherm which is indicating the domination of the microporous structure of these catalysts [4,34]. At the same time, according to Freitas et al. [35], the H-β and H-Y zeolites can combined isotherms with type I and IV, which indicates on some possibility of low amount of mesoporous structure in the studied materials which can also be observed in Fig. 1 and Table 1. On the other hand, the H-ZSM-5 and H-USY pristine and NiMo-modified catalysts show type IV isotherms typical of micro- and mesoporous materials with the typical H4 hysteresis loops which are related to the hierarchical porous system with size-homogeneous 1D slit channels [36]. No changes in the type of isotherms and the shape of the hysteresis loop, between promoted and unpromoted catalysts were observed, when Ni and Mo species were added to the corresponding zeolite support. This suggests that the pore structure of the supports is preserved stable after metals impregnation [37]. The results obtained above are also correlated with the pore size distribution analysis (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method). As shown in Fig. 1c the pore size of the HZSM-5 and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts is around 62.5 Å, which indicates the mesoporosity of studied catalysts. A similar trend was observed for the H-USY and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY catalysts with 37.9 and 154.4 Å and the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y catalyst with the pore size of 37.9 Å (Fig. 1c and d). The HF was calculated for all studied samples to evaluate their enhancement of the mesopore surface area [38]. It was found (Table 1) that H-USY, 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/USY, HY, H-Mordenite, and 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/Mordenite catalysts displayed moderate HF ≤ 0.1 with microporous nature, while H-ZSM-5, 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/ZSM-5, 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/Y, H-Beta, and 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/Beta catalysts achieved HF > 0.1, which indicates on the presence of some mesopores. The 2.5 %Ni2.5 %Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst shows one of the highest HF values (0.14) but lower than the H-ZSM-5 catalyst (0.16), while the catalytic performance of the first one was higher. This behavior can be explained by HF “blinding” to the nature of the acid sites [38]. Thus, the textural properties showed the enhanced mesopore volume and pore diameter after Ni and Mo incorporation into H-ZSM-5 zeolite framework. Fig. 2 presents the XRD patterns of the studied catalyst samples. No apparent peaks from Ni and/or Mo species were detected. This can be attributed to the low metals loading, high dispersion, and/or small undetectable particles of the Ni and Mo species on the zeolite support which is in the line with literature data [17,26]. The Scherrer's equation (using FWHM values) was used for the determination of the crystallite size, where the latter is different from the particle size measured by HRSEM and/or HRTEM. It is known [40] that one particle can be constituted by several crystalline domains (crystallites), this is the main reason that the particle size has to be bigger than crystallite (domain) size, while the crystallite size calculated from XRD must be much smaller than particle size from HRSEM. This conclusion is completely consistent with our experimental results (Table 1 and Fig. 3 ). It was observed that all zeolite supports (H-ZSM-5, H-USY, H-Y, H-Mordenite, H-Beta) demonstrated the existence of MFI, BEA, FAU, MOR topological structures related to them and a high degree of crystallinity with strong intensity diffraction peaks in the 2θ region at 23.1, 23.3, 23.7, 23.9, 24.4° (Fig. 2b) and 20.4, 22.4, 23.3, 23.7° (Fig. 2d). Impregnation of Ni and Mo species into zeolite supports led to the decrease of crystallinity in the range of 6.2–38.2 % (Table 1, Fig. 2) but the overall crystal structure of zeolites was preserved. It was found that after consideration of 7 diffraction peaks (2θ: 78.0°, 8.9°, 23.1°, 23.3°, 23.7°, 24.0°, 24.5°) the relative crystallinity of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo-ZSM-5 catalyst was decreased to 80.2 %. The 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY catalyst shows decreasing to 86.9 % after consideration of 9 diffraction peaks at 2θ: 6.3°, 10.3°, 12.1°, 15.9°, 18.9°, 20.6°, 24.0°, 27.4°, 31.8°. In the case of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y sample the observed crystallinity decreased to 61.8 % at 2θ: 6.3°, 10.2°, 12.0°, 15.7°, 18.8°, 20.5°, 23.8°, 27.2°, 31.6°. The 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite catalyst exhibited decreasing to 91.1 % at 2θ: 9.8°, 13.5°, 15.3°, 19.7°, 22.4°, 25.7°, 26.4°, 27.7°. Finally, the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta crystallinity decreased to 93.8 % at 2θ: 7.9°, 21.5°, 22.5°, 27.1°. Thus, the highest crystallinity decrease was observed for the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts with 38.2 % and 19.8 % crystallinity decrease, respectively. These results can be explained by the highest amount of Ni and Mo “real” loading to zeolite H–Y and H-ZSM-5 identified by ICP-OES. The excess of Ni and Mo metals are not able to form bonds with Si and as a result the relative crystallinity decreases [41]. High-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HRSEM) study was carried out for the elucidation of the crystalline structure and morphologies of the catalyst samples. Fig. 3 presents the typical images of the zeolite supports and NiMo-promoted zeolite catalysts. Significant changes in crystallinity and/or shape between zeolite supports and bimetallic zeolite catalysts were not detected. In Fig. 3A and B the irregular hexagonal-shape crystal morphology of the H-ZSM-5 and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts can be seen with the particle size of 174 ± 67 nm and 99 ± 17 nm, respectively. Fig. 3C-D exhibited SEM micrographs of the H-Beta and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta catalysts with spherical-shape particles with a size of 379 ± 103 nm and 366 ± 106 nm, respectively. This is in line with other literature findings [37]. Fig. 3E and F showed the octahedral crystal morphology of the H-USY (365 ± 64 nm) and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY (283 ± 76 nm) catalysts. Fig. 3G and H also presented the octahedral crystal morphology for the H-Y (713 ± 161 nm) and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y (505 ± 153 nm) catalyst samples. Finally, the H-Mordenite and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite samples showed the rod-like particles with the sizes around 1011 ± 229 nm and 934 ± 289 nm, respectively. Interestingly, all studied samples showed a relative decrease in particle size after the impregnation of Ni and Mo species. This phenomenon can be explained by the error of particle size measurements and/or by the effect of grinding and crushing on the synthesized catalysts [42]. The size of the crystals decrease in a row: H-Mordenite > 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite > HY > 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y > H-Beta > 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta > H-USY > 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY > ZSM-5 > 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5. It can be observed that the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst possessed the lowest particle size if we compare the latter with other studied catalysts. Fig. 4 presents micrographs of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst sample. The investigations were carried out in the bright field (BF-STEM) and high-angle annular field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) mode. It was found that some Ni particles with an average size of 22.4 ± 5.6 nm on the zeolite external surface had hexagonal and spherical shapes [3]. In the case of Mo particles, we can observe that the main part of them is located inside of zeolite framework, which is correlated with the Energy-Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDXS) mapping. The EDXS mapping and X-ray energy-dispersive spectrum (XEDS) of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst is shown in Fig. 5 , which proves the presence, composition, and distribution of elements existing in the specific area that is shown. The EDXS and XEDS confirmed the presence of Ni, Mo, Si, Al, and O elements in the studied catalyst. The EDXS mapping shows that Ni metal nanoparticles (green color) can be attributed to the location of them on the HAADF-STEM micrograph, while the main part of Mo nanoparticles (turquoise color) does not correspond to the particles on the micrograph. This indicates on their internal location. It can be seen that Ni particles are partly agglomerated on the zeolite surface and not uniformly distributed in the zeolite framework, while Mo particles are distributed much better inside zeolite channels without significant agglomeration [43–45]. The main reason of the low dispersivity of Ni naonparticles is agglomeration. According to Khodakov’s group [45] the Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst prepared by conventional impregnation method is covered by large agglomerates of NiO species with preferential localization outside the zeolite crystallites due to low diffusivity of hydrated bivalent Ni2+ cations into zeolite micropores. Thus, the HRTEM/EDXS analysis proved the presence and exhibited the location of Ni and Mo nanoparticles in the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst. 3.2 Surface acid and reduction properties The NH3-TPD-MS profiles of pristine zeolites and NiMo-modified zeolites are displayed in Fig. 6 . All samples exhibited two desorption peaks (Table 2 ): the first one in the range of 190.7-203.9 °C corresponding to the weak acid sites, and the second one in the range of 312.9–452.3 °C, which can be attributed to the medium-strong acid sites [46–48]. It is interesting to note that all samples after Ni and Mo addition to zeolite supports showed shifted peaks position from the higher to lower temperature zones. This indicates on a decrease in the amount of the strong acid sites and increase in the amount of medium acid sites. Besides, the results show that all NiMo-modified zeolite catalysts included both weak, moderate Brönsted acid sites (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS), which is in good agreement with the literature data [49]. When Ni and Mo metals were loaded on the zeolite supports, a significant increase of the first desorption peak (weak acid sites), excluding only 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite catalysts, was observed. After deconvolution, the amount of acid sites was evaluated (Table 2). The total acidity increased after the loading of metals for all studied catalysts, excluding the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y sample, which is correlated to the literature results [50,51]. Fig. 7 presents the pyridine-DRIFTS spectra of the zeolite supports and NiMo-modified zeolite catalysts desorbed at 125 °C. The bands at 1450, 1544, and 1490 cm−1 were attributed to the pyridine absorption on LAS, BAS, and both BAS and LAS, respectively [28,52]. It can be observed that after the impregnation of Ni and Mo species to zeolite lattice the intensity of the absorption bands at 1544 cm−1 corresponding to vibrations of pyridine chemisorbed on BAS is decreased for all NiMo-promoted zeolite catalysts. Moreover, it was found that the ratio of BAS/LAS was also decreased, excluding the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite catalyst, which exhibits an insignificant increase from 1.5 to 1.6, while the total acidity was also increased and in agreement with the literature data [50]. According to the obtained Pyr-DRIFTS analyses, the amounts of BAS and LAS (in percent) were both quantified, and their details are summarized and presented in Table 2 below together with BAS/LAS ratio. The most significant decrease of BAS/LAS was observed from 2.5 to 1.5 over the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. At the same time, the total acidity of the latter was higher than the parent HZSM-5 zeolite. This phenomenon indicates the increasing amount of medium LAS due to the formation of extra-framework Al species (EFAL), which leads to the partial turning of BAS into LAS [25]. This tandem between EFAL and BAS stimulates the increase of the strength of acid sites [53], and thus, enhances the catalytic activity. It can be seen that BAS/LAS = 1.6 for the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite catalyst which is just slightly higher comparing to the Mordenite with BAS/LAS = 1.5. This deviation can be attributed to the experimental error. For instance, Zhou et al. [31] observed a similar deviation for the BAS/LAS ratios in the NiMo/HMY-x series catalysts. Moreover, the weak/strong site changes after metals deposition in our study are well correlated with the same literature data [31]. After Ni and Mo impregnation to parent zeolites, it was observed that the appearance of additional mesopores is correlated with significantly increased levels of weak and strong LAS, while the major part of BAS is decreased. The H2-TPR profile of the most active catalyst (2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5) is shown in Fig. 8 . After the deconvolution (Fig. 8B) the TPR profile presented shows three peaks between 250 and 750 C°, indicating the formation of varying Ni and Mo species on zeolite support. The low-temperature peaks at 365.1 and 405.9 °C can be ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ species and octahedral Mo species from Mo6+ to Mo4+ [26,27,54]. The high-temperature reduction peak at 620.9 °C can be attributed to the partial or full reduction of the Mo4+ and/or Mo2+ species to MoO. According to the literature [55], the broadness of the signal in the high-temperature zone can be explained by the coexistence of agglomerated Mo oxide species with different coordination degree. 3.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated on a packed-bed reactor at 370 °C under atmospheric pressure with LHSV1-MN+NP =1.0 h−1 and H2/1-MN + NP = 9000 (volume ratio). The liquid products generated were carefully collected and analyzed offline using GC-FID and/or GC–MS, while the gas products were identified online by micro-GC. The example of product distribution over 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst is presented in Fig. 9 . It is worthy to note that only 2-MN was detected as the main reaction liquid product for all tested catalysts at 370 °C under ambient pressure. This behavior can be attributed to the enhanced thermodynamic stability of the 2-MN which in agreement with the literature [20]. Fig. 10 shows the total conversion of NP and 1-MN mixture and selectivity of 2-MN after 18 h time-on-stream over H-ZSM-5, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5, H-USY, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY, H-Y, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y, H-Mordenite, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite, H-Beta, and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta catalysts. The order towards 2-MN selectivity decreasing can be expressed as follows: 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite < H-Beta < H-ZSM-5 < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta < H-Mordenite < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY < H-Y < H-USY. It should be also noted that the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the enhanced selectivity (96.0 %) based on the liquid products towards 2-methylnaphthalene (Fig. 10). At the same time, the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite and H-ZSM-5 catalysts also showed high 2-MN selectivity (94.5 % and 91.2 %, respectively), but the conversion of 1-MN and NP in feedstock mixture was lower. Thus, we can speculate that the balance between the catalyst acidity, pore diameter, and mesopore volume is responsible for the high product selectivity. It was found (Fig. 11 ) that the amount of gaseous product mixture (ethylene and propane) is decreased as follows: 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY < H-Y < H-USY < H-Beta < H-ZSM-5 < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y < H-Mordenite < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta. Our gas products were identified by micro-GC which was calibrated for the gas products. This is well consistent with the literature data. According to Corma et al. [6] the relatively large amounts of ethylene (ethene) together with propane were identified over ZSM-5, Beta, MCM-22, ITQ-2, USY, UTD-1, and Al-MCM-41 zeolites from decalin at 450 °C under atmospheric pressure. In our product mixture, we observed some amounts of tetralin, 1-methyltetralin, 1-methyltetralin, 6-methyltetralin due to NP and 1-MN hydrogenation reaction which can easily undergo subsequent hydrogenation into decalin with the following generation of ethylene and propane gas product mixture. Fig. 11 shows that the most active catalysts (2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY, and H-Y) generate the highest amount of gas products (ethylene and propane mixture) with 94.2, 93.8, and 90.8 wt.%, respectively. This is attributed to the difference in the structural, textural characteristics, and surface acid properties, which have been already mentioned above. Fig. 10 shows that the total conversion of NP+1-MN mixture decrease in the following order: 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 < H-Y < H-USY < H-Beta < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y < H-ZSM-5 < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta < 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite < H-Mordenite. The highest total conversion was observed over 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 (96.3 %), 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY (97.5 %), and H–Y (96.3 %) catalysts. The lowest total conversion was found over H-Mordenite (72.9 %) sample, while the addition of Ni and Mo metals decreased the total conversion only for the H-Beta and H-Y zeolite catalysts. Based on the obtained physico-chemical characterization of catalyst samples we can assume that combination of catalyst acidity, mesopore volume, and pore diameter have significant impact on the total conversion of biomass tar model mixture and 2-MN, ethylene and propane products selectivity. The connection between catalyst activity and acidic/textural characteristic is complexed and can not be expressed straightforward via dependence in one figure. It was found that there is no perfect fit correlation between all structural and acid properties of studied catalysts and total conversion but we strongly believe that combination of mild total and medium and strong acidity, relatively high mesopore volume and pore diameter provide high catalytic performacne in the reaction of conversion of biomass tar model compounds. This statement is also in agreement with the literature results [4,20]. We speculate there is exist a global optimum where all of the mentioned above parameters are perfectly balanced but unfortunately, it is complicated to prepare the exact catalyst with controlling all of these optimal parameters. The 2.5Ni2.5Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is probably closer to the optimal values than other samples. According to the properties shown in Tables 1, 2, and Fig. 10 the most similar are 2.5Ni2.5Mo/H-ZSM-5 and H-USY catalysts, while their morphology is different. In the case of catalyst selectivity, it can be seen that the H-ZSM-5 and H-Beta zeolite supports are the most selective but after the addition of Ni and Mo species the H-ZSM-5 increases the selectivity and conversion, while the opposite effect was observed for the NiMo-modified Beta zeolite, even the total acidity was increased in both cases. Table 2 shows that the total acidity of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/H-ZSM-5 and H-Beta catalysts are comparable. At the same time, it was found (Table 1) that the mesopore volume and pore diameter of these catalysts are significantly different. In addition, the changes of the mesopore volume and pore diameter are different after loading of Ni and Mo metals to H-ZSM-5 and H-Beta. For the H-ZSM-5 increases in the mesopore volume and especially in pore diameter are observed, while for the H-Beta zeolite it is almost the same. Thus, based on the pysico-chemical analyses and catalytic evaluation study it was found that the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 sample is the most active and stable catalyst in comparison with other studied catalysts in the reaction of NP and 1-MN conversion into valuable products with observing of the mono- and bimolecular competing mechanisms. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, there are no published results in the literature regarding application of bimetallic zeolite catalysts for the conversion of a binary mixture of NP and 1-MN under ambient or high pressure. Fig. 12 shows the comparison of the catalytic activity and selectivity under atmospheric pressure between the most active synthesized catalyst and the literature results. It can be seen that our 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst has the highest total conversion (96.3 %) with the selectivity of 2-MN (96.0 %) in the liquid phase after 18 h, while the product was collected after 0.25−1 h time-on-stream for all presented catalysts from the literature. This indicates that our catalyst in current reaction conditions is more stable due to enhanced mesopore volume, pore diameter, and adjusted (mild) catalyst acidity after Ni and Mo incorporation into H-ZSM-5 zeolite framework which is also supported by physico-chemical property measurements. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, there are no studies in the literature related to the conversion of a binary mixture of NP and 1-MN under atmospheric pressure. It is known that the mechanism of hydrocracking of NP and/or 1-MN is complicated and includes many parallel reactions [56]. Based on the experimental results of product distribution the simplified reaction pathway (Scheme 3 ) is proposed for the conversion of NP and 1-MN mixture over 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst under atmospheric pressure. Isomerization, alkylation, and hydrocracking reactions are considered as the main reactions that occur with 2-MN as the main liquid product and ethylene and propane as the main gas products, respectively. According to the literature [57], the obtained product distribution can be explained via the classical hydrocracking mechanism for PAHs on bifunctional zeolite-supported catalysts, which involved hydrogenation, hydrocracking, isomerization, disproportionation, ring opening, condensation, and alkylation reactions. Based on the previous literature results [6,12,56–59], we can assume that the studied reaction pathway is attributed to the monomolecular mechanism at long reaction time on stream (more than 10 min) which competes with the bimolecular path. The monomolecular route over 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst includes the ring-opening of the aliphatic ring of tetralin and 1-methyltetralin from NP and 1-MN, and acid-catalyzed isomerization of the 1-MN molecule into thermodynamically more sTable 2 -MN. According to Guerzoni and Abbot [18], the 1-MN isomerization reaction occurs through the methyl group shift along the aromatic ring on the weaker acid sites of zeolite. In the case of hydrogenation of NP and 1-MN, the trace amounts (tetralin and 1-methyltetralin) of this reaction were identified in the product mixture. The hydrogenation reaction is carried out on acid sites of zeolite or metal species which can catalyze the migration of spillover hydrogen [58]. The monomolecular pathway produced butylbenzene via ring opening of methylindan where the latter compound was identified in trace amounts. At the same time, butylbenznene undergoes secondary cracking into light alkanes and alkenes (propane, ethylene), benzene, and lower alkylbenzenes, which are confirmed by the product mixture analysis. The bimolecular path leads to the formation of benzene and tricyclic aromatic compounds, the traces of which were identified in the product mixture and are presented in Scheme 3. Moreover, this pathway is responsible for coking and catalyst deactivation due to chain reactions. Coke was also observed on the spent catalysts. The amount of coke was quantified for the most active catalyst (2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5) and compared with other NiMo-modified zeolite catalysts (2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite, 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY) via total carbon (TC) analysis using Rosemount Analytical Dohrmann DC-190. It was established that the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 possessed the lowest amount of carbon (2.4 wt.%) comparing to the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Beta (11.7 wt.%), 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Y (17.3 wt.%), 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite (4.7 wt.%), and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/USY (14.6 wt.%). This resistance to the coke formation of the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst can be explained by its mild total acidity and different type of zeolite frameworks [60,61]. Indeed, the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 and 2.5Ni2.5Mo/Mordenite catalysts with the lowest total acidity exhibited the lowest amount of carbon (Table 2), while other NiMo-modified catalysts with higher total acidity have much higher carbon deposition. Thus, based on the pysico-chemical analyses and catalytic evaluation study it was found that the 2.5Ni2.5Mo/ZSM-5 sample is the most active and stable catalyst in comparison with other studied catalysts in the reaction of NP and 1-MN conversion into valuable products with observing of the mono- and bimolecular competing mechanisms. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, there are no published results in the literature regarding application of bimetallic zeolite catalysts for the conversion of a binary mixture of NP and 1-MN under ambient or high pressure. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of bimetallic zeolite catalysts were prepared by the wet-impregnation method and evaluated in the reaction of biomass tar model compounds (5 wt.% naphthalene +95 wt.% 1-methylnaphthalene) hydrocracking and isomerization at 370 °C under atmospheric pressure. The addition of Ni and Mo species to a set of various zeolite supports (MFI, BEA, FAU, MOR) had a positive effect on catalytic performance for the major part of tested catalysts. The obtained results indicate that pore size and topology have a strong impact on catalytic selectivity, activity and stability. The 2.5Ni2.5Mo-ZSM-5(30) catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic stability (with resistance to carbon deposition), activity (Xtotal =96.3 mol%) for the hydrocracking (ethylene and propane, 94.2 wt.%), and isomerization reactions into 2-methylnaphthalene with selectivity in the liquid phase of 96.0 mol% after 18 h, in comparison with other studied catalysts. The surface acidity study shows that the addition of Ni and Mo species lead (for the most active catalysts) to an increase in LAS amount, medium-strength acidity, and total acidity, while BAS/LAS ratio is decreased. Thus, the present study shows that the combination of the amount of medium and strong acid sites, increased pore diameter, and mesopore volume are essential and affect the catalyst performance in the reaction of biomass tar model compounds into valuable products. The monomolecular pathway in competing with bimolecular are the most probable mechanisms for the naphthalene and 1-methylnaphthalene conversion on bifunctional acid catalyst under atmospheric pressure. coredata.dc:description: In this experimental study, various NiMo-promoted (as follows: H-beta, H-mordenite, H-USY, H-Y, and H-ZSM-5) catalysts were prepared, tested, and compared with pristine zeolites for the purpose of the gas phase hydrocracking, hydrogenation, and isomerization in a packed bed reactor at 370 °C under atmospheric relative pressure. 5 wt.% naphthalene/95 wt.% 1-methylnaphthalene were selected as biomass tar model molecule compounds, based on real chemical compositions. A series of material characterization techniques were applied to determine the physical structural, morphological, textural, redox, and acidic properties of synthesized catalysts. An outstanding catalytic activity and stability were found over the 2.5 wt.% Ni–2.5 wt.% Mo/ZSM-5 with high carbon deposition resistance, 2-methylnaphthalene selectivity (96.0 mol.%) in the liquid with the products with a yielded total conversion of 96.3 mol.% after an 18 h time on stream, where ethylene/propane were main (94.2 wt.%). The latter can be attributed to the presence of mesopore volume/surface area, existing boundary interface, the amount of medium/strong acid sites, and the synergetic interaction phenomena between metal atom species/supports. Attention should be paid to particle size dimensions, diameters and acidity, which facilitated poly-aromatic hydrocarbon removal. Considering particular obtained distributions, intermediates reaction pathway was proposed. Cracking, synthetic ring opening, alkylation, condensation and disproportionation were additionally involved. Results were consistent with the occurrence of two competing mechanisms, a monomolecular, as well as a bimolecular one.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrocracking, hydrogenation and isomerization of model biomass tar in a packed bed reactor over bimetallic NiMo zeolite catalysts: Tailoring structure/acidity
